section.name: About this Document
section.p: This document describes user functionality that will be built in Phase 1 of the Cytoscape Data Services project. The focus of Phase 1 is to provide similar data services functionality to that provided in Osprey.

section.name: Feature #1: Obtain Node Information from GRID
section.P:
For each node in the graph, Cytoscape will download node information from GRID. For each node, information will include:
ORF Name(s)
Gene / Alias Name(s)
Description
Gene Ontology Information
GO Component
GO Process
GO Function
GO Special
All of this data will be displayed in a separate window. Initially, data will be presented in the same manner as currently used by Osprey (basically, a simple panel of tables and text boxes.) In a later phase, we will redesign the data presentation to follow the new Cytoscape look and feel guidelines.

In Phase 1, the user will see one option under the Cytoscape PlugIn menu:
Get Gene Information from GRID

When the user selects this option, Cytoscape will download information about all nodes within the graph and cache the contents locally in memory. Cytoscape will then pop-up a new "Gene Information" window. When the user select an individual node, the Gene Information window will be updated to show the selected node data. If no node is selected, the window will not show any data.

section.name: Feature 2: Obtain additional interaction data from GRID
section.P: Just like in Osprey, a user will be able to select a specific node, and then view node information within the "Gene Information" window. Within this window, we will include a "Get New Interactions" button. When the user clicks on this button, Cytoscape will connect to GRID, download a full list of interactions and display the list to the user. The user can then add all of these interactions to the graph.
Again, for Phase 1, we will follow the design already provided by Osprey.

section.name: Technical Features
section.P: This first phase of the project will follow the general guidelines put forth in our Data Services Technical architecture document. Phase 1 will therefore include: First iteration of Cytoscape data services layer; and Use of Java Caching System.

section.name: Schedule
section.P: Phase 1 should take approximately two weeks of development. Assuming we nail down user functionality by Wednesday, April 23, we can start real coding on Thursday, April 24. Phase 1 should therefore be complete by Friday, May 9. This includes time to create unit test scripts via JUnit, create a better Ant build process, and tweak the user interface.
